author: .vshvsh
content: hey! Vasiliy from Lido (lido.fi) here. We think it's an absolutely crucial feature, and I just made a comment in an issue to lay put our reasoning: https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/issues/2040#issuecomment-713037071

author: .vshvsh
content: TLDR we think that  the only credible competition to staking derivatives is custodial liquid staking on exchanges;  and refusing to add a mechanism for staking derivatives doesn't help self-staking, but just pushes less technical people to use more centralized exchanges.

author: jgm
content: Someone needs to build out a plan for how to handle this on the ETH1 side, though.

author: .vshvsh
content: That's how we are handling this

author: .vshvsh
content: You can't make a good contract for withdrawals when no one is sure how exactly it's going to work but you can make a placeholder that's going to be upgraded when phase 1.5+ is out

author: jgm
content: The problem is, if there is no definition of what is required then there is no guarantee that users will definitely deploy upgradable contracts.  They may use an unupgradble contract, or supply an EOA.  In those situations the staked Ether is lost.  Which is why some sort of definition is required so that users know the expectations on them when supplying an ETH1 address.

author: .vshvsh
content: I think withdrawals should and will be designed in a way eoas will work. Supplying credentials of a contract that can turn out bricked is on the supplier though
